prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not going to my best friends wedding.
So my best friend (lets call her G) has decided to have her wedding, that's awesome and I'm happy she found the one. 

The issue is G never sent out save the dates, meaning last week we got the actual wedding invitations for a wedding that is happening in 1 month.  

It will be at her grandmother's Ranch and it seems like a pretty nice wedding. 

here is where the issue started. 

a few months ago me and 3 friends decided to plan a trip to Australia to backpack/sightsee for 2 weeks, the trip starts 2 days before the wedding so we can't go. G knew about the trip as we invited her but I'm geussing she forgot. 
she is mad at all of us for not just cancelling the trip and being at her wedding. 

all of us are not super rich so this would be a huge loss if we cancelled the trip. (so we are not) 

I also want to add that she invited 50 people, I asked. and only 20 can make it as she gave 1 month notice. 

she is flipping her shit and acting like we should drop everything for her. 

AITA for not just cancelling my 2 week trip to go to her wedding? 
"""

I think the author is not in the wrong, but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking whether the author of the AITA post is in the wrong for not attending their best friend's wedding because they had a planned trip to Australia that conflicts with the wedding date.

First, the friend (G) didn't send a save-the-date, only the actual invitation a month before the wedding. The author and three friends had planned an Australia trip months ago and had invited G. Now, G is upset that they can't cancel the trip to attend her wedding. The author argues that the trip is expensive and there's a short notice, so they can't cancel.

So, the main points are: G didn't give enough notice (only a month), the trip was planned in advance and is a big financial commitment, and G is now acting like they should drop everything. The author is trying to balance their prior commitments with attending the wedding.

I think the key factors here are the lack of save-the-date and the short notice. Weddings usually require save-the-dates to give guests time to plan. G's failure to send one makes it hard for the author to adjust their plans. Also, the trip was planned in advance and G was invited, so the author had no reason to believe there was a wedding until the last minute. The author isn't being selfish; they're trying to honor a commitment they made, especially since it's a significant expense. G's reaction seems unreasonable given the circumstances. So, the author is not in the wrong.
